metadata.case_name: Petitioners (Advocates of Calcutta High Court) v. State of West Bengal & Ors.

facts.text: Four petitioners are advocates enrolled in Calcutta High Court between 1948 and 1952, entitled to appear and plead in Original and Appellate jurisdictions, generally practice on Original side.

In 1956, petitioners called to English Bar by Middle Temple, notified Registrar Original Side to add 'Barrister-at-Law' to names, but had not read for 12 months in chambers of practising Barrister in England or Calcutta as required by Original Side rules.
Original Side rules classify advocates into: (1) Barrister read 12 months in chambers; (2) Barrister not so read; (3) Law degree holders passing tests.
High Court maintains List I (Barristers-at-Law enrolled) and List II (other advocates).
Court building portion allotted to advocates sub-divided: Bar Library Club (List I advocates) and Bar Association (other advocates).
Petitioners added 'Barrister' to names but not admitted to Bar Library Club; suffer disability as litigants/solicitors prefer Club members.
Petitioners and another advocate represented to Chief Justice for equal accommodation; informed not entitled as no 12 months chambers reading.
Suit in City Civil Court (Title Suit No. 339 of 1958) pending in 1960 on similar rights, later withdrawn; petitioners informed Chief Justice could not act due to pendency.
Petitioners claim discrimination gives impression Club members (English Bar) superior to Indian Bar advocates, prejudicing profession; rules ultra vires Indian Bar Councils Act.
Separate accommodation provided for: (1) Barristers enrolled under Original Side rules; (2) Advocates enrolled by High Court; (3) Attorneys.
History: Free accommodation to Barristers since 1825 in Supreme Court, continued in High Court; Bar Library Club for Barristers, Bar Association for others, Incorporated Law Society for Attorneys.
Accommodation for bona fide professional business; licensees rent-free, maintain electricals.
Chief Justice minute: Persons called under Consolidated Regulation 43 not entitled as Barristers unless read 12 months and enrolled.
Bar Library Club resolution June 14, 1957 confirmed Feb 14, 1958: No admission for advocates called under Regulation 43.
Supreme Court order April 16, 1962: Adjourned to allow petitioners approach Chief Justice on Art. 14 issue.
Petitioners represented to Chief Justice May 11, 1962; Bar Association May 22, 1962, claiming no distinction, Art. 14 violation.
Chief Justice reply June 21, 1962 via Secretary: Desirable for amalgamation, throw open rooms to both from July 1, 1962 for Centenary.
Amalgamation failed; Bar Association intervened July 1962, allowed Sept 27, 1962.
Bar Library Club amended rules March 2, 1962: Admit non-Barrister advocates who practise Original Side, confine to pleading only; three admitted, more applications.
Accommodation: Attorneys 2 rooms, Bar Library Club 4 rooms (plead only), Bar Association 6 rooms (plead and act).
Historical background: Separate roles since Supreme Court; Vakils vs Barristers; Indian Bar Councils Act 1926 and Advocates Act 1961 unified Bar.
Club Rule 1 amended: Includes Barristers and other Original Side advocates as Committee determines; Rule 25 allows limiting numbers based on accommodation.
Solicitor-General intimated withdrawal of Rule 25 limitation for no discrimination; admission on merits for plead-only advocates.

legal_issues.text: Whether allotment of separate accommodation to different sections of Bar (Bar Library Club, Bar Association, Attorneys) in Calcutta High Court building violates Article 14 equality before law.
Whether Original Side rules requiring 12 months chambers reading for List I Barristers discriminate and are ultra vires.
Whether petitioners entitled to use Bar Library Club rooms as advocates called to English Bar.

petitioner_arguments.text: All advocates enrolled for Original Side entitled equally to all accommodations without distinction; separate space for Club discriminates, creates superior class impression, prejudices profession.
Rules for Original Side requiring chambers reading ultra vires; no need for further reading as already enrolled advocates.
Should be one Bar Association, no separate allotment to Club.

respondent_arguments.text: Accommodation allocation administrative matter for Chief Justice; reasonable classification based on historical branches: plead-only Barristers (Club), plead&act Advocates (Association), act-only Attorneys.
Bar Library Club private association, no writ against it or members; discretionary admission, no legal right to membership or rooms.
Petitioners not qualified Barristers under rules without chambers reading; entitled only as Appellate Side advocates.
No fundamental right enforceable under Art. 32; mere licensees, no cause of action.

court_reasoning.text: Historical process since 1765, Supreme Court 1825 accommodations; British system introduced distinctions, but Acts of 1926 and 1961 unified Bar; vested interests persist.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unification desirable but requires mutual agreement; past cannot be wiped out completely.

court_reasoning.text: Three categories reasonable: (1) plead only (Club), (2) plead and act (Association), (3) act only (Attorneys); serves litigant interests, Court efficiency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification based on nature of practice reasonable, no Art. 14 violation.

court_reasoning.text: Club amended rules to admit plead-only non-Barristers without discrimination (Rule 25 limitation withdrawn); improvement achieved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to interfere; Chief Justice to ensure implementation.

court_reasoning.text: Guided by public good for efficient Bar assistance to Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hopes for unified Bar with best traditions.

holdings.text: Classification into three sections (plead only, plead and act, act only) reasonable given history; separate accommodation not denial of equality under Art. 14.
Bar Library Club rules amended to admit plead-only advocates without discrimination; no interference needed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality before law; enforcement of fundamental rights via writ.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Bar Councils Act, XXXVIII of 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Unified Bar, equal rights of audience by seniority.

outcome.summary: Petition dismissed as classification of Bar sections and accommodation allotment reasonable, no Art. 14 violation; Bar Library Club agreed to non-discriminatory admission for plead-only advocates.
outcome.relief_granted: None; noted Club's undertaking and Chief Justice to ensure implementation.

key_quotes.text: "Grant of separate accommodation therefore to these three sections of the Bar cannot amount to denial of equality before the law."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "This classification in our opinion is reasonable taking into account the past history to which we have already referred."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We have been chiefly guided by considerations of public good, that is to say, that the Court should be assured of efficient and willing assistance from the Bar."
key_quotes.speaker: court
